citation.article-title: Thermoanaerobium acetigenum spec. nov., a new anaerobic, extremely thermophilic, xylanolytic non-spore-forming bacterium isolated from an Icelandic hot spring.

p.s: Description of Thermoanaerobium acetigenum, sp. nov.
Thermoanaerobium aceligenum (a.ce.ti.ge'num. L.N. acetum vinegar. L.V. genere, gignere to produce. M. L. neutr, adj. acetigenum, vinegar or acetic acid producing)
Cells stain gram-negative but have a gram-positive cell wall structure, occurring singly and in pairs, about 3.6-5.9 μm long and 0.7-1.0 μm wide.
Sometimes in chains up to 8 cells.
Off white, milky coloured colonies formed on solidified xylan containing medium.
At pH 7, growth between 50 and 78°C with an optimum at 65-68°C (doubling time: 4h).

Growth between pH 5.2 and 8.6, with and optimum around pH 7 and 68°C Arabinose, cellobiose, fructose, D-galactose, D-glucose, lactose, maltose, mannose, raffinose, soluble starch, sucrose, trehalose, D-xylose and xylan supported growth.
On glucose and D-xylose, acetate, CO2, H2 ethanol, and traces of isobutyric acid are formed, but not lactate.
DNA base composition of 35.7 (±0.8) mol% G + C.
Single strain isolated from a biomat and sediment from a slightly alkaline hot spring at Hveröagerdi, Iceland.
Type strain. Thermoanaerobium acetigenum X6B has been deposited at DSM (DSM 7040) as the type strain of the species.
